comments.commentBody:
It''s of passing interest to note that about 47% of American voters can never be convinced to vote for Romney - including voters of many categories.

A campaign looking to garner victory would not spend money chasing the votes of those absolutely committed to voting for the other guy.

Romney and his minions will work overtime to weasel out of this one. The spin doctors are already at work telling us what he really meant.

We we just heard what he really means and thinks. I for one will take him at his word. Or is he prevaricating? There is about 47% of the population that will agree with what he said. We see that on these pages frequently. That tells us something about their and his character.

Notice how he tells us what this nefarious 47% believe. I do not see a PhD in Psychology or Sociology after his name, but he expects the rest of us to believe he knows what he is talking about. He has dressed himself up as some sort of guru of American culture and made the indictments of close to half the population of the country. Hell, we don't need no studies, research, statistics, we have Romney to tell us everything we need to know. Just ask him.

I personally find his comments to be offensive. His opprobrium knows no bounds, it is the mind of a seriously deranged individual. We have seen a few of these madmen in my lifetime, some of them even lived in the U.S. but were caught and put away.

I have worked with thousands of people in the past years. Four years in the AF, years in the aerospace industry, even on missile silos and a shipyard. Many of those jobs were government financed I do not remember my fellow workers considering themselves government dependents, that the government owed them jobs. We earned our pay, and the country profited from it.
You're almost as good as Romney in artfully dodging and weaving while avoiding the real issues raised. Or maybe it's just your talent for stringing together non-sequiturs.
Perhaps you're one of the 53%, Bryan? You seem to be trying to defend remarks that are pretty indefensible from a man who who has the aspiration to be President of all Americans.

The mistake you people make is that you don't see that redistribution of wealth goes hand in hand with having a job.
redistribution of wealth simply means progressive taxation, but you falsely translate it into hand me downs, and Ronnie "Propagandist" Reagan welfare queens...
Romney hates veterans, because they don't pay taxes.

Good column, Maureen. It would do you a lot of good if you would just relax a little and not consider that Governor Romney is the answer to all your prayers in your effort to assure the reelection of President Obama. Since, as we know so well, all is fair in love, in war, and in US Presidential elections, the happy event for the Democrat party that Governor Romney has offered at this juncture of the campaign as we now reach 49 days to go, is manna from heaven for the President, just in time as the facts on the events in Egypt and Libya begin to emerge. There is a long way to go and curiously the race is a long way from the home stretch.

Reporters and columnists reflect their preferences, and even their biases from time to time, and politicians do too, since they tailor their address, most particularly those delivered to small groups of the like minded, to suit the objective of the day. The upcoming three debates now become even more enthralling since the agenda is already beginning to take shape. And the VP Biden Vs Congressman Ryan exchange of views promises to be a real treat.

An interesting development is the prior recordings of these men being bandied about in the media. My favorite is of course the admission by then candidate Senator Obama in 2007, that he was a champion of redistribution of the wealth of the nation. Governor Romney says that he prefers employment for all and the creation of national wealth. That is a stark contrast indeed. And key to the result.
Perhaps, but the Christian churches hold their services on Sunday,  the day that the Romans worshiped the sun god, not Saturday, proscribed in the 10 commandments as the day that must be held sacred.

Well -- no they do not.

A chunk of that 47% are the elderly on Social Security. They don't pay payroll tax, nor income tax (on the first $25,000).

A big chunk are workers who work "under the table". This is a big part of the economy! I've been forced to do this many times in my work life; I paid no payroll tax (and now will suffer less Social Security as a result). It wasn't my choice, it was the employer refusing to pay their share.

So we are talking about two different things -- those that pay payroll tax, but not income tax -- and those who pay neither.

Lastly: I doubt there are unemployed folks or students who are "rich with good tax lawyers".

It’s true that almost half of the people in the US pay no income taxes, but most of those pay payroll taxes. The only difference between those two is that payroll taxes are paid directly out of your paycheck, rather than on April 15th. The percentage that pays neither payroll nor income taxes is 17%. In 2007 that figure was 14%. The majority of this group are Seniors, Disabled, Unemployed, or in school. And some of them are very rich with good tax lawyers. All of these people who drive, however, pay Federal Gasoline Tax, and almost all of them pay Social Security Tax.

http://www.cbpp.org/cms/index.cfm?fa=view&id=3505
WOW. So many people who call themselves Christians and yet are so poorly educated about their own religion.
Wonderful Jesus gets a front page of the New York Times 2012 years later. Pretty neat!
What's your source on John Mark and Jesus supposedly being lovers.  I have read a fair amount of Gnostic literature but have never seen that.

Mr. Williams states that the Library of Alexandria was burnt by "Islamic fanatics". The library was originally set ablaze in AD47 by Julius Caesar (yep, that guy) and then hysterical arsonist Christians did the heaviest damage ever recorded to the collection in AD391 if I remember correctly. The Coup de Grace was done by invading Muslim troops who came from present day Saudi Arabia in AD600+ (?) but the damage was made to whatever Christians had left over for others to damage. When it comes to religion there is no such thing as a moral high ground to a specific religion. Were the fanatics of Islam any different to the fanatics of Christianity?

Funny how you say we should "not jump to conclusions until we have some kind of proof or evidence" in reference to a religion that has never established any "proof or evidence" that its God actually exists or that "He" put forth one single word or idea contained in the Holy Bible. But we have seen that religious conservatives really aren't interested in truth, are they?

The date of this would certainly be later than 33 AD, there are no documents from the time of Christ dealing with his life.  Almost all the documents about Jesus are retellings of retellings of oral histories from his followers, most of whom couldn't write and were often poor.  It wasn't until many decades after his death that any writings about Jesus appeared, and was not until several dozen to several hundred years later that the standard set of texts about his life came about and much later than that that there was a consensus on which texts were valid and which weren't. You may not be aware that in the ancient world literacy was pretty rare, and almost non-existsent among the poor.  Our understanding of the life of Christ was probably written down by people for whom his life was as remote in the past as the civil war or revolution is to us!

Religious zealots do not seem interested in any but their own 'truth' either.
What is a 'religious liberal' anyway?

I am a layman, but I see additional possibilities in this matter.

1. What is the date of this? If it is later than 29 to 33 AD (I use this dating system), then there is plenty of time for first or second or third or even fourth century revisionists to somehow come up with a wife for Jesus. The holy grail here is whether ot not the text is authentic. No one apparently cares whether or not it's true.

2. Jesus had a wife. It is the Church of the New Testament in the New Testament, and the Jewish people in Tanakh. In the New Testament, the church is called the Bride of Christ. Without any context--the fragment is smaller than a business card, remember?--we apparently have no idea of the full intent of the writer. Was the context speaking of a wife in the Biblical sense? Or was it an error on the part of a Coptic writer--a misstatement? (You guys let Obama get away with this all the time.)

3. That this Jesus is not Jesus Christ, but another Jesus. There were many men named Jesus in that part of the country, apparently.

So let us not jump to conclusions until we have some kind of proof or evidence. We have neither here in a fragment. We have datum. In time, it may become either proof or evidence. But we have seen that religious liberals really aren't interested in truth, are they?
Yeah, it's a good thing it's not 1254...
Or 1492 during the Inquisition.

"Mockery of religion is one of the most essential things because to demystify supposedly 'holy text dictated by god' and show that they are man made and what you have to show [is] there [are] internal inconsistencies and absurdities. One of the beginnings of human emancipation is the ability to laugh at authority... it is an indispensable thing, people can call it BLASPHEMY if they like, but if they call it that, they have to assume there is something to be blasphemed - some divine work. wWell I don't accept the premise." ~ CHRISTOPHER HITCHENS

(Emphasis mine)

One could interpret this individual's statements as blasphemous and an insult to Catholics and Christians alike. Where is the moral outrage and when do the protests start?

In a free and open society, public discourse is welcome.

Why is suggesting that Jesus was married is "speaking a word against the Son of Man?"
Why would Jesus entering into holy matrimony make him less than divine?

I am glad we are discussing Jesus and not another Prophet of some other faith for which we could all incur the death penalty. Christianity is amazing!

Matthew 12:32
Anyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but anyone who speaks against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven, either in this age or in the age to come.

Yes, I overheard a work colleague say to his friend on the phone yesterday that he was "planning on voting for Romney because he was less likely to mess with the second amendment". I forwarded him the politifact article that explains that it's a pants on fire lie that Obama's coming after our guns.

We cannot allow good people to be duped into voting this selfish sociopath into the office of the POTUS!

What's at stake here is virtually everything we've built over the last 100 years.

If you're not outraged by what the republicans are trying to pull off, you are not paying attention.
Oddly, many of those among that much disdained 47%.
This is true--they think he's right and don't think that he's talking about them as everybody has been saying he has to be.
What bothers me about Willard's 47% remarks is that millions of Americans hooked on Rush Limbaugh, Fox News, and right-wing talk radio believe exactly what he said.

Stuart K -- Of course it was illegal, once the pay question had been settled to the advantage of the union, to an extent which you call "very superior".  The City took it to court on Monday, and the judge thoughtfully deferred it to Wednesday so the union could call off the strike on Tuesday afternoon, which it did.  I am not sure the students of Chicago are better off observing their teachers breaking the law.  And I have no idea what your last sentence has to do with anything.
Sounds good!  Why don't you take the lead on this and start teaching tomorrow.  I'm sure that it's as simple as you describe.

Granted, actions have consequences. But are you saying that, in perpetuity, Muslims are entitled to exact revenge for the wrongs done by the Roman Catholic Church during the reign of Ferdinand & Isabella? The historical perspective you offer is interesting, but I'm not sure what your point is.

Well that's one way of looking at it. This idealization of Muslim rule in medieval Spain is a persistent trope among certain commentators who pride themselves on understanding the "other."
Another way of looking at it is that Ferdinand and Isabella liberated Spain from an aggressive, expansionist Islam that had reached deep into France before being turned back. And a more sophisticated reading of Muslim Spanish history would acknowledge that intra-Muslim strife among competing rulers and principalities also contributed to the downfall of this civilization
And on the architectural and art front, perhaps it's also useful to acknowledge that Greek Christian artists and artisans were brought in by Muslim patrons to help design and build all those beautiful Andalusian structures because they were masters in mosaics and glass. After all, there was a glittering Byzantine Christian civilization in the East in Constantinople that somehow gets lost in the sunny vision of a refined and sophisticated medieval Muslim culture fighting off barbaric Western European Christian hordes.
Alas, Constantinople in turn fell to Ottoman Turk hordes in 1453.
Actions indeed have consequences.

Your time frame and facts are a bit off. The Umayyads were overthrown (and mostly of the ruling family killled) by the Abbaids who in turn were overthrown by the very conservative (jihadist) Almoravids, who demanded non-Muslims convert or leave.

There was a time when Islam was the tolerant religion, where a Jew was the adviser to the Emir and a Christian was the envoy to Damascus.

This was the Umayyad branch of Islam and it was destroyed by the Roman Catholic Church when Isabella and Ferdinand became the Rulers of Spain. they were the leaders in medicine, mathematics and Philosophy. That was in Andalusia where we now go to see the great structures they built like the Alhambra, which the Christians desecrated by adding on an ugly uninspiring addition.

By the dictates in Rome, the Andalusian Christians were not the right kind of Christians, the Jews and Muslims were heretics, so that society was destroyed. thus we have been left with the Abbasid branch of Islam that we have today.

There are two good books on Islam.
"Destiny Disrupted" by Tamim Ansary, see http://www.mirtamimansary.com/
The other is:
"The ornament of the World" by Maria Rosa Menocal.

Actions have consequences.

I think at the time that most in the North considered the Southerners to be citizens of the United States in rebellion. Otherwise what was the point of "preserving the Union". As for today. . . if people born in the Southern states aren't americans then what are they?

I couldn't disagree more with the comments of JR and tom franzson. JR- When (if) you go to the fringes of Coney Island (or another disenfranchised community) and walk into the tight spaces of the subjects' apartments and living spaces, come back and talk about interest and immediacy. Instead of making this about how you personally would choose to make a frame, try stepping back from the bias of Ms. Berl not being a big name photographer and appreciate her work for the beautiful snapshot of life that it is.
I can also appreciate consistently approaching the same community and attempting to see it from a different angle each time. It's not an easy task, and I think that Ms. Berl has done an extraordinary job making a new and visually striking, personal frame on each visit.
Remarkable vision.
Marvelous visual images. Strong. Evocative.
The same is true for Obama--he turned out to be someone radically different from the public creation during the election.
Please don't insult Hoover by comparing Mitt to him.  The one who deserves that insult is Warren G. Harding, with Cal Coolidge in the Paul Ryan seat.
Being President doesn't change who you are...it reveals it.

In all the Conservative analysis I've read of Romney's media faux pas this conclusion appears to unite them: not WHAT Mitt said, but THAT he said it and it's been broadcast.

Ross Douthat today associated Mitt with G.W. by pointing out that G.W. chose to create an image of himself for public consumption and stuck with it, never diverting from that contention.

Of course, who G. W. turned out to be after he was elected by the Supreme Court, was radically different from the public creation.

This campaign is revealed for what it is, an electoral coup, a takeover of American society for a government of a wealthy elite, by a wealthy elite, and for a wealthy elite.

God knows, otherwise they might perish from this earth.

1928 here we come. Mitt is definitely no G. W. Mitt's Hoover.

Just to set the record straight, Theo Van Gogh was a Dutch filmmaker who was murdered for a movie he made depicting the mistreatment of women in Islamic society. You're confusing his assassination with the controversy over a Danish newspaper's publishing of cartoons depicting Muhammad. Van Gogh had no involvement with that.

For your edification.

Van Gogh made a film titled “Submission:. He had no role in the production of the cartoons produced by 12 Danish cartoonists.

The film “depicted four partially nude women in long dark transparent veils, who had texts from the Koran written in calligraphy on their bare skin. Some of the women appeared to have reddened whip marks on their backs and legs, on which the texts were written that described the physical punishments, sanctioned by the Koran for disobedient women.”

the film also touched upon rape, adultery, and arranged marriages.

60 Minutes: “On a busy Amsterdam street, in broad daylight, a prominent film maker named Theo van Gogh was shot, stabbed and mutilated in front of dozens of witnesses.”

"Van Gogh was murdered on Linnaeus Street in Amsterdam. He was shot several times by a bearded young man. As he lay dying, Van Gogh was reported to have begged for mercy, and said, "Can't we talk about this?" But the man shot him again, slit his throat and stabbed him, pinning a letter to his body.”

The letter was addressed to a woman, Hirsi Ali.

Some info on her and why the letter was addressed to her: “The script for Submission was written by a Dutch parliamentary deputy, Ayaan Hirsi Ali, a Somalian national. She represents the right-wing Freedom and Democracy Party (VVD) in parliament and is known as a critic of Islamism. Following the showing of the film Submission, both Hirsi Ali and Theo van Gogh received murder threats over the Internet.

"...Yet we tend to coexist well and acts of savage hatred related to criticism or loathing of religion are relatively rare...."

I suspect that is because we are a largely, historically, secular society with separation of church and state embedded in our national consciousness. No one religion has ever been allowed to become a state-sponsored religion, to the detriment of any other. Our laws are founded in humanity, though they can and do reflect principles and beliefs found in many religions.

Thank you Tom for your fresh perspective. It is illuminating to see the loathing which some in the Muslim faith have. Most of us have seen what rabid fear and hatred can do, as in the killing of many innocents in the 9-11 incidents, death threats against Salman Rushdie for his publication of a book not favorable to Islam, the intensely brutal slaying of Theo Van Gogh for his act of publishing cartoons ridiculing a prophet of Islam.

That is not to say any society or group is free of prejudices and hatred. Something I do find in America which I love is the often irreverent humor and lampooning of just about every religion and certainly every politician. Yet we tend to coexist well and acts of savage hatred related to criticism or loathing of religion are relatively rare.

In listening to some enlightened voices in Muslim, as was seen in the Times last week with the publication of a picture of two women holding a sign condemning violence, I am heartened that many are awakening. I am hopeful that leaders of Islam, though rightly offended by such a disrespectful and hateful video as recently appeared, will speak out for tolerance, understanding and forgiveness, and against endless and needless violence.

Da, Comrade Lasz, We Muscovite Dr. Shteyman back real soon, should it Don on us?

Howie

Wow! This is Wednesday? I shudder to think what awaits us on Thu-Fri-Sat. Which other Wednesday puzzle in recent memory had 10 clues (I think) with question marks?

I loved the challenge though. Even the common crosswordese short fill was so cleverly clued that almost none were gimmes. I could spend my 1500 letters only on the superb misdirections that struck my fancy, not to mention the quality of the longer entries (6 letters and above).

I was a little surprised at the unconventional symmetry of the theme answers. But who cares? It is still an exceptionally fresh and totally enjoyable puzzle.

Thank you, Michael. Come back soon, you hear?
The emus must be snoozing.
Let's cut your salary in half while we're at it.

Well, they are not, so don't worry about it.

Actually there is no such theory. You probably thinking of the faux genealogies that purported to show that certain early European royals were descended from a cousin of Jesus.
